We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Why You Should Hire Me as Your Next IT Engineer🔹 My Journey in IT EngineeringFrom the beginning of my career, I have been passionate about technology, security, and automation. I started as an IT professional managing servers and troubleshooting network issues. Over time, I dived into DevSecOps and Cloud Computing, gaining expertise in AWS, Azure, Linux Administration, CI/CD pipelines, and Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools like Terraform and Ansible.Throughout my journey, I have worked on streamlining IT operations, automating deployments, and strengthening cybersecurity measures. My goal has always been to create IT solutions that are not only efficient and scalable but also secure and resilient.🔹 What Makes Me Different?Many IT engineers can fix problems, but I focus on preventing them before they occur. Here’s how:✅ Security-First Approach – I integrate DevSecOps principles into IT operations to ensure secure deployments and protect against vulnerabilities.✅ Automation & Efficiency – I automate repetitive tasks to reduce downtime, minimize human errors, and increase productivity.✅ Cloud Expertise – Whether it’s migrating applications to the cloud or optimizing cloud resources, I ensure businesses maximize their cloud potential.🔹 My Key Skills & ExpertiseIT Infrastructure & Cloud Computing: AWS, Azure, Google CloudAutomation & DevOps: Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform, Ansible, CI/CD pipelinesCybersecurity & DevSecOps: Firewalls, SIEM solutions, Penetration Testing, Secure CodingSoftware Development & Web Technologies: Python, JavaScript, Linux AdministrationNetwork Administration & Troubleshooting🔹 My Impact in Previous RolesIn my past roles, I have successfully:🚀 Reduced deployment time by 50% by implementing a fully automated CI/CD pipeline🚀 Enhanced network security by configuring firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and multi-factor authentication🚀 Optimized cloud infrastructure, resulting in cost savings and improved performance🚀 Developed secure web applications by following industry-standard security practices🚀 Trained teams on cybersecurity best practices, significantly reducing security risks🔹 Looking for My Next OpportunityI am currently open to new opportunities where I can contribute my skills and help businesses scale their IT operations, improve security, and implement efficient DevSecOps strategies. If your company is looking for an IT Engineer, DevSecOps Specialist, or Cloud Security Expert, I’d love to connect!hashtag#ITEngineer hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#DevSecOps hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#Cybersecurity hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#LinuxAdministrator hashtag#Automation hashtag#TechJobs hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#NowHiring hashtag#SoftwareEngineer

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Why You Should Hire Me as Your Next IT Engineer🔹 My Journey in IT EngineeringFrom the beginning of my career, I have been passionate about technology, security, and automation. I started as an IT professional managing servers and troubleshooting network issues. Over time, I dived into DevSecOps and Cloud Computing, gaining expertise in AWS, Azure, Linux Administration, CI/CD pipelines, and Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools like Terraform and Ansible.Throughout my journey, I have worked on streamlining IT operations, automating deployments, and strengthening cybersecurity measures. My goal has always been to create IT solutions that are not only efficient and scalable but also secure and resilient.🔹 What Makes Me Different?Many IT engineers can fix problems, but I focus on preventing them before they occur. Here’s how:✅ Security-First Approach – I integrate DevSecOps principles into IT operations to ensure secure deployments and protect against vulnerabilities.✅ Automation & Efficiency – I automate repetitive tasks to reduce downtime, minimize human errors, and increase productivity.✅ Cloud Expertise – Whether it’s migrating applications to the cloud or optimizing cloud resources, I ensure businesses maximize their cloud potential.🔹 My Key Skills & ExpertiseIT Infrastructure & Cloud Computing: AWS, Azure, Google CloudAutomation & DevOps: Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform, Ansible, CI/CD pipelinesCybersecurity & DevSecOps: Firewalls, SIEM solutions, Penetration Testing, Secure CodingSoftware Development & Web Technologies: Python, JavaScript, Linux AdministrationNetwork Administration & Troubleshooting🔹 My Impact in Previous RolesIn my past roles, I have successfully:🚀 Reduced deployment time by 50% by implementing a fully automated CI/CD pipeline🚀 Enhanced network security by configuring firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and multi-factor authentication🚀 Optimized cloud infrastructure, resulting in cost savings and improved performance🚀 Developed secure web applications by following industry-standard security practices🚀 Trained teams on cybersecurity best practices, significantly reducing security risks🔹 Looking for My Next OpportunityI am currently open to new opportunities where I can contribute my skills and help businesses scale their IT operations, improve security, and implement efficient DevSecOps strategies. We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment



…more

Today, let's delve a bit into history and examine the evolution of the term 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐮𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 :) The term's main development occurred from the 1990s to the early 2000s.In 1991, CI was defined as 𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐝𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐬' 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲, with no specific requirements on frequency. Between 1997 and 1999, the requirement to integrate code from individual developers with the main branch clarified to 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚 𝐝𝐚𝐲.In the early 2000s, the first CI tools began to appear, and as a result, the 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐬 from at least the main development branch became CI best practice. As of now, CI is de facto associated with automatic builds, though de jure it is still defined as the necessity to merge into the main branch at least once a day.And 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 Continuous Integration for yourself?hashtag#UnitTesting hashtag#TestDrivenDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Why You Should Hire Me as Your Next IT Engineer🔹 My Journey in IT EngineeringFrom the beginning of my career, I have been passionate about technology, security, and automation. I started as an IT professional managing servers and troubleshooting network issues. Over time, I dived into DevSecOps and Cloud Computing, gaining expertise in AWS, Azure, Linux Administration, CI/CD pipelines, and Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools like Terraform and Ansible.Throughout my journey, I have worked on streamlining IT operations, automating deployments, and strengthening cybersecurity measures. My goal has always been to create IT solutions that are not only efficient and scalable but also secure and resilient.🔹 What Makes Me Different?Many IT engineers can fix problems, but I focus on preventing them before they occur. Here’s how:✅ Security-First Approach – I integrate DevSecOps principles into IT operations to ensure secure deployments and protect against vulnerabilities.✅ Automation & Efficiency – I automate repetitive tasks to reduce downtime, minimize human errors, and increase productivity.✅ Cloud Expertise – Whether it’s migrating applications to the cloud or optimizing cloud resources, I ensure businesses maximize their cloud potential.🔹 My Key Skills & ExpertiseIT Infrastructure & Cloud Computing: AWS, Azure, Google CloudAutomation & DevOps: Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform, Ansible, CI/CD pipelinesCybersecurity & DevSecOps: Firewalls, SIEM solutions, Penetration Testing, Secure CodingSoftware Development & Web Technologies: Python, JavaScript, Linux AdministrationNetwork Administration & Troubleshooting🔹 My Impact in Previous RolesIn my past roles, I have successfully:🚀 Reduced deployment time by 50% by implementing a fully automated CI/CD pipeline🚀 Enhanced network security by configuring firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and multi-factor authentication🚀 Optimized cloud infrastructure, resulting in cost savings and improved performance🚀 Developed secure web applications by following industry-standard security practices🚀 Trained teams on cybersecurity best practices, significantly reducing security risks🔹 Looking for My Next OpportunityI am currently open to new opportunities where I can contribute my skills and help businesses scale their IT operations, improve security, and implement efficient DevSecOps strategies. If your company is looking for an IT Engineer, DevSecOps Specialist, or Cloud Security Expert, I’d love to connect!hashtag#ITEngineer hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#DevSecOps hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#Cybersecurity hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#LinuxAdministrator hashtag#Automation hashtag#TechJobs hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#NowHiring hashtag#SoftwareEngineer

Today, let's delve a bit into history and examine the evolution of the term 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐮𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 :) The term's main development occurred from the 1990s to the early 2000s.In 1991, CI was defined as 𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐝𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐬' 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲, with no specific requirements on frequency. Between 1997 and 1999, the requirement to integrate code from individual developers with the main branch clarified to 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚 𝐝𝐚𝐲.In the early 2000s, the first CI tools began to appear, and as a result, the 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐬 from at least the main development branch became CI best practice. As of now, CI is de facto associated with automatic builds, though de jure it is still defined as the necessity to merge into the main branch at least once a day.And 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 Continuous Integration for yourself?hashtag#UnitTesting hashtag#TestDrivenDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Today, let's delve a bit into history and examine the evolution of the term 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐮𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 :) The term's main development occurred from the 1990s to the early 2000s.In 1991, CI was defined as 𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐝𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐬' 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲, with no specific requirements on frequency. Between 1997 and 1999, the requirement to integrate code from individual developers with the main branch clarified to 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚 𝐝𝐚𝐲.In the early 2000s, the first CI tools began to appear, and as a result, the 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐬 from at least the main development branch became CI best practice. As of now, CI is de facto associated with automatic builds, though de jure it is still defined as the necessity to merge into the main branch at least once a day.And 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 Continuous Integration for yourself?hashtag#UnitTesting hashtag#TestDrivenDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Today, let's delve a bit into history and examine the evolution of the term 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐮𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 :) The term's main development occurred from the 1990s to the early 2000s.In 1991, CI was defined as 𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐝𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐬' 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲, with no specific requirements on frequency. Between 1997 and 1999, the requirement to integrate code from individual developers with the main branch clarified to 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚 𝐝𝐚𝐲.In the early 2000s, the first CI tools began to appear, and as a result, the 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐬 from at least the main development branch became CI best practice. As of now, CI is de facto associated with automatic builds, though de jure it is still defined as the necessity to merge into the main branch at least once a day.And 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 Continuous Integration for yourself?hashtag#UnitTesting hashtag#TestDrivenDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified

If you’re stacking jobs and ghosting meetings, don’t be surprised when companies start wondering if they need any of us at all.Earlier today, a buddy pinged me with this article: “A Gen Xer's plan to earn $800K this year across 6 remote jobs: Hiring people to be him.” I read it, shook my head, and thought—man, we really need to talk about this. I know some people won't be "happy" with my take on this but: on one hand, I get it. We all want more security, more freedom, and yeah, more money. Stack a few remote jobs, outsource some tasks, keep your head down, and ride the wave while it lasts. There’s even a part of me that respects the hustle. But here’s where I get stuck. I’m that guy sitting in the Zoom call with his camera on, actually trying to move the project forward… and wondering why the other guy—who, let’s be honest, never shows up—is MIA again. Yeah, the work might get done. Eventually. Kind of. But now I’m questioning the whole setup. And if that’s the game we’re playing, wouldn’t it just be easier for companies to automate your job with AI? If you’re not showing up as a human, why do we need you at all?I don’t say that lightly. I’ve been the guy trying to get a foothold, looking for the next gig, making ends meet. And back in the day, I probably would’ve thought this whole job stacking thing was brilliant. But now? I’ve spent enough time on the other side of the table—building teams, leading projects—to see how this stuff plays out. It’s not just "getting your bag." It makes people jaded. Hiring managers start side-eyeing anyone who wants "more" remote work. Talented folks looking for their first shot get passed over because companies are too burned to take a risk. So yeah, I get it. But we have to talk about the collateral damage here. Does this help us or hurt us in the long run?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TeamBuilding hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Today, let's delve a bit into history and examine the evolution of the term 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐮𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 :) The term's main development occurred from the 1990s to the early 2000s.In 1991, CI was defined as 𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐝𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐬' 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲, with no specific requirements on frequency. Between 1997 and 1999, the requirement to integrate code from individual developers with the main branch clarified to 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚 𝐝𝐚𝐲.In the early 2000s, the first CI tools began to appear, and as a result, the 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐬 from at least the main development branch became CI best practice. As of now, CI is de facto associated with automatic builds, though de jure it is still defined as the necessity to merge into the main branch at least once a day.And 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 Continuous Integration for yourself?hashtag#UnitTesting hashtag#TestDrivenDevelopment

We at Odyssey Global are Hiring for Azure Cloud Engineer for one of our Renowned client with below required skills.Job Title: Sr. Azure Cloud EngineerJob Location: Fully RemoteCitizenship Status: USC/GC OnlyJob Description:The Sr. Azure Cloud Engineer is responsible for the support and maintenance of cloud infrastructure with a focus on resource optimization, organizational management and governance. This is going to be a 9-week contract position•A Bachelor's degree is required; equivalent experience will be accepted in lieu of degree.•Must have hands on experience managing Azure-based, highly redundant or resilient production systems.•Must have experience with Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling•Must have experience with Azure Resource Management•Experience in helping IT teams understand how data moves across networks•Must have experience in Azure configuration documentation•Must have experience in organizational management and governance including resource tag review, troubleshooting, and Azure backup configuration.Top Skills:•Write/ run and implement a runbook in Azure•How would you test backups?•Documenting network topology?•Custom Azure Build Out (documentation, cradle to grave) – not DevOps background•Manual development (they do not want someone coming from large scale  automation.•Network Diagram Creation - IP Routing/ subnetting. Enterprise App Review: • Review the 545 Enterprise apps in our Azure environment. • Document and recommend which apps should be removed based on Sign-on logs and Certification expiration records.Azure Backup Configurations:• Review Azure backup configurations. • Test file-level and VM-level restore playbook, documenting results and making recommendations where necessary.Azure Patch Management:• Plan, configure, and deploy Azure Patch management to replace WSUS. Resource Tag Review:• Review all resource tags.• Correct and update non-standardized tags.Azure Configuration Documentation:• Create documentation of current Azure environments, including Subscriptions, POCs, VNets, routing, VMs, etc.Network Diagram Creation: • Create a detailed network diagram of Azure VNET peering and routing. • This requires a fundamental understanding of IP routing and subnetting.Azure Virtual Desktop Scaling:• Configure Azure Virtual Desktop scaling.Azure Resource Management:• Perform Azure resource management duties by working with stakeholders to create and update subscriptions for projects.• Work with the change management team to document all proposed updates, access control, and security.Azure Environment Troubleshooting:• Assist with troubleshooting access to Azure resources, systems.If you or Someone in your Network are perfect,DM me or share the CV to krish@odysseyca.com.hashtag#Cloud Engineer #ITJobs# #AzureJobs#CloudEngineeringJobs#RemoteJobs#ContractJobs#AzureCertified
